newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch money dealers split on move after repo cut.
newsitem.headline: Dutch money dealers split on move after repo cut.

text.p: Dutch money market dealers were divided on whether the Netherlands will follow Germany's rate cutting lead this afternoon and trim its special advances.
The Dutch central bank will set a new special advances pact at 1400 GMT. The rate is currently fixed at 2.70 percent.

Some dealers said the Dutch central bank would cut the special advances by 10 basis points as the current guilder-mark rate did not give space for a stronger trimming of the special advances, while other dealers said the bank would not change the rate at all for the time being.
"The central bank is likely to wait and see if the guilder strenghtens further against the mark before it will cut the special advances," said one.
The guilder was trading at 112.175 per 100 marks versus 112.17 on Wednesday.
Dealers said the repo cut was stronger than expected.
Dutch money rates started slowly moving down after the German cut, but call money remained stable at 2.81 percent bid. Three-month deposits shed 10 basis points to 2.88 percent bid.
